newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan TI-Acer in T$5.1 bln IC testing venture.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan TI-Acer in T$5.1 bln IC testing venture.

text.p: Taiwan semiconductor joint venture TI-Acer Inc said on Tuesday it would launch a T$5.1 billion venture to build an integrated circuits testing plant on the island to cope with rising memory chip demand in 1997.
"To cope with the rising demand for dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips in 1997, our board meeting just decided to join in the venture," spokeswoman Ruth Pao told Reuters.
Major partners include TI-Acer with 19 percent, Acer Inc 15 percent, Chiao Tung Bank 10 percent, China Development 10 percent, and the remainder by individual shareholders, Pao said.
TI-Acer is a venture between Texas Instruments and Taiwan computer giant Acer. Acer has a 48 percent stake, TI 33.34 percent and the rest is held by other investors.
The integrated circuit venture, located in Taiwan's nothern town of Lungtan, would focus on memory chip testing, especially DRAMs, Pao said.
"Construction has already started, with completion seen in the third quarter of 1997," she said.
By 1998, the plant's monthly testing capacity would be 10 million chips, she said.

TI-Acer, one of Taiwan's leading DRAM chipmakers, said in June that it was halting production of four-megabit DRAM chips because months of price-slashing had made it virtually unprofitable. It said it would focusing on production of 16-megabit chips instead.
